Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Parsimonious Modeling via Matrix Minimization

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual merit:

In many engineering applications, notions of complexity, order or dimension of a model can be expressed by the rank of a matrix, while prior information and model accuracy often correspond to convex constraints on this matrix. Parsimonious Modeling involves the computational problem of minimizing matrix rank subject to convex constraints. Examples include problems in system identification, model reduction, and Euclidean embedding, arising in control, signal processing, and machine learning. The rank minimization problem is known to be computationally intractable in general. The work is inspired by the recently developed framework of compressed sensing for sparse signals. A preliminary work by the PI and her collaborators, points to a rich generalization of this theory from sparse vectors to low-rank matrices, showing that some classes of this hard problem can be solved efficiently.

The proposed research builds on advances in compressed sensing and its underlying math, as well as convex optimization. The program has three thrusts: (1) theoretical characterization of classes of rank minimization problems that can be solved efficiently, (2) development of efficient semidefinite programming algorithms for this problem, (3) a focus on applications of rank minimization (e.g., in system identification). This program combines practical impact with conceptual depth, unifying existing notions of parsimony (such as vector sparsity and matrix rank) as well as the computational methods to address them.

Broader impact:

This program will leverage extensive collaborations between pure mathematicians and engineers, and should motivate research in mathematics in areas not traditionally considered ?applied". Results and computational tools developed can be used by researchers in various application fields. Research from this project will be integrated with the PI's past work into a new project-driven graduate course at UW. Students at all levels will be engaged. A workshop and a mathematical problem solving competition is planned as part of UW's BRIDGE program for incoming women and minority freshman.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project broadly focused on finding parsimonious models and hidden low-dimensional structures in high-dimensional data. With advances in sensing technologies and exascale computing, researchers in every engineering discipline are faced with major challenges in modeling, analyzing, and identifying behaviors from high-dimensional data. In this project, we developed theory and algorithms that help make these tasks possible despite highly incomplete and noisy information, by exploiting prior knowledge about model structure, where “structure” is defined broadly and includes common concepts such as sparsity, group-sparsity, low-rank matrix structure, and low-rank tensor structure.

Our work initiated low-rank matrix methods as a subarea in several disciplines; significant research effort has since been devoted to these methods and they have been employed in machine learning, signal processing, and increasingly in control and system identification. Our results include (1) theoretical foundations for low-rank matrix reconstruction given limited measurements, where we discovered the minimization of matrix nuclear norm (trace norm) achieves information-theoretic limits (under certain measurement schemes), (2) efficient algorithms for nuclear norm minimization using problem structure, (3) iterative reweighed algorithms for enhanced performance (achieving sparser and lower-rank solutions), (4) application to several areas via collaborations with domain experts, including machine learning (e.g., collaborative filtering, language modeling), classical system identification (identifying low-order linear dynamical system from input/output measurements), statistical modeling (e.g., learning structured graphical models), and new applications in signal processing (e.g., the phase retrieval problem).

This project brought together ideas and techniques from engineering, mathematics, and computer science. The results were disseminated through publications in archival journals (one of which has more than 1500 citations in Google Scholar), peer-reviewed conference proceedings, theses and preprints posted online, and through invited and plenary talks given by the PI. The plenary talks were given at main conferences of different research communities, including Linear Algebra (at Intl. Linear Algebra Society Meeting, 2013) and Signal Processing (SPARS 2015). The PI proposed and organized a 4-day multi-disciplinary workshop at IPAM (NSF-supported institute) on `Structure and Randomness in System Identification and Learning’ involving control engineers and data scientists, which bridged the gap between these two fields to explore the role of structured models.


This project partially supported the training PhD students and an undergraduate student. Our undergraduate researcher won departmental and university-wide research awards for her research related this project. A graduate student won a departmental best research award, and another student won a best paper award at the conference Uncertainty in Artificial Intelligence. 


As it evolved, the project led the PI to new areas and new collaborations (with researchers in biostatistics, language processing, machine learning, and communications) beyond what was planned at the start. Through these collaborations new applications were explored, and in turn motivated new theoretical questions (for example, what happens when a model has several structures simultaneously, which is a topic the PI is currently exploring).
